title: Why do the German contestants in the Eurovision Song Contest mostly get such bad scores? - Quora

response.answer_text: A2A: For me, there are two main reasons. Quality of music: The German entries from about 2004 (when I started watching) until the present haven’t exactly been great. There have been some distinct standouts - I was partial to Texas Lightning’s “No No Never”, loved Roger Cicero’s “Frauen regier’n die Welt” and was fond of Roman Lob’s “Standing Still” - and one incredibly impressive winner in Lena’s “Satellite”. In general terms, though, Germany’s not really entered something with the “oomph” to win, certainly when you compare the German entry in a given year with the winner in the same year. This isn’t just a German problem, I should point out. The “Big Four” (or by now “Big Five”) who are pre-qualified for the final have all been accused of phoning their entries in pretty often. Italy, since their return, have entered at least three legitimate contenders (“Folia d’amore”, “Grande amore” and 2017’s exercise in wit and silliness “Occidentali’s Karma”), Spain appears to at least be trying at the moment, and France has shown some evidence of interest (“Je cherche” in particular) but also enters rubbish like “Moustache”. And of course there’s the UK, the less of which we speak the better. Exactly why this is, I don’t know. I’ve read a lot of suggestions that because those five countries don’t have to fight through a qualification process (and, with the exception of Italy, don’t always have a highly competitive national final), it might have bred a level of complacency. Compare them to Sweden, for example, which puts every potential entrant through the wringer of Melodifestivalen (in some years, I’d argue that the top 4–5 Melodifestivalen entries could win the Eurovision of that year), only to then have to go through a semi-final every year for the chance to turn up at the final. No wonder someone like Sanna Nielsen or Måns Zelmerlöw - both serial Melodifestivalen entrants - brought their A-game to Eurovision. Voting Patterns: This isn’t one of those “everyone votes for their neighbours, so Eurovision’s rigged” things. The take-home message of my first point is that if you have a good song, Europe votes for you in big numbers. The issue, is, though, that in a year where you have a so-so song, or there’s no true standout, Germany doesn’t have “buddies” in the way that some of the rest of the continent does. Take the Düsseldorf contest (2011) as an example. Now, I’m not going to say “Taken By A Stranger” should have won, but “Running Scared” (which did) didn’t win by all that much. Realistically, there were a fair few songs which could have/should have won that year. What mattered was the ability to sway a handful of votes to go to Azerbaijan, rather than anyone else. Why so? Azerbaijan was already attracting a decent number of votes from the former Soviet states and Turkey, so it had a “base” ready to roll. The same would apply in terms of a Scandinavian or Balkan entry - there’s a reason at least one Scandinavian entry is in the higher reaches of the scoreboard, and why one Balkan entry tends to be as well. While there are Germans living and working all over Europe, though, they don’t equate to the “diaspora” that some other countries enjoy. Germany customarily voted in droves for the Turkish entry when the Turks were entering, because of the size of that diaspora, for example. Germany (and the other Big Five, to be frank) don’t have that going for them.

I think that’s simply because the rest of the EBU countries simply hasn’t liked their music lately. Most people seem to have forgotten Roman Lob and him ending up in 8th place in 2012 (personally I thought that deserved top 3 - love that song), and they ended up winning in 2010 (that song I wasn’t very fond of though). Also, when Ann Sophie ended up in last place, the voting rules were different. If it had been now, she would, at least, not end up with no points at all. I honestly kind of liked that song - I loved her voice, at least. The last few years just hasn’t gone that well for them. For some reason, the voters just haven’t been that fond of their songs. Sad but true. Why the juries haven’t been that kind either, I can’t say.
